item.title: College Majors Success Rates
item.description: Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting Majors Dataset majors <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/fivethirtyeight/data/master/college-majors/recent-grads.csv") level_key <- c("Computers & Mathematics" ="Natural Sciences", "Engineering" = "Natural Sciences", "Industrial Arts & Consumer Services" = "Business", "Biology & Life Science" = "Natural Sciences", "Agriculture & Natural Resources" = "Natural Sciences", "Physical Sciences"= "Natural Sciences", "Health" = "Natural Sciences", "Social Science" = "Liberal Arts", "Humanities & Liberal Arts" = "Liberal Arts", "Psychology & Social Work" = "Liberal Arts", "Education" = "Liberal Arts", "Law & Public Policy" = "Liberal Arts", "Arts" = "Communication", "Communications & Journalism" = "Communication") majors <- majors%>% select(Rank, Major, Total, Men, Women, Major_category, ShareWomen, Employed, Unemployed, Unemployment_rate) %>% mutate(MoreWomen = ifelse(ShareWomen > 0.

item.title: Evaluating Movies based on the Bechdel Test and Movie Ratings
item.description: Project 1: Exploratory Data Analysis library(readr) next_bechdel_test <- bechdel_test <- read_csv("SDS 348_bechdel_test.csv") movie_ratings <- read_csv("IMDB-Movie-Data.csv") Introduction The Bechdel test, also known as the Bechdel-Wallace test, is a measure of how women are represented in movies. When it was first created in 1985, there were only 3 critera for a movie to pass the test: 1. the movie must have (at least) two named women in it 2. who talk to each other 3.
